history.content:
Some related classes: 

CS 184, as you mentioned

CS 284B

CS 194-26 (Computational photography -- not sure when it will be offered again, perhaps in the spring)

You mentioned ML applications, so:

CS 280 (Computer vision)

CS 182 (Deep learning)

Related:

UCBUGG Decal teaches you how to make a 3D animated short in Maya; not really programming/ML related, but if you're interested in applications it's a good way to get exposure (plus it's super fun)

Game design/development (Decals, occasionally classes from art history/art practice) are also a fun application

Professor Ng is teaching Computational Color next semester (CS294-164) but I'm not sure what the pre-reqs are or if it would be offered again in the future

There's occasionally a graduate level course in VR/immersive computing

Relevant faculty would probably include (I might be missing some!): Ren Ng, Alyosha Efros, James O'Brien, Brian Barsky, Hany Farid, and Bjorn Hartmann

children.subject: Also keep in mind that EE 120/123 are considered computational/inferential depth for data science. but 184 is not.
Also if by 'animations' you mean ML application sin animating/rigging, you may want to look into classes in robotics/simulation

I honestly think EE is better for this.

I would highly recommend EE 120/123/225B to get a better sense of the math that goes into constructing computer images and videos. These classes will teach about image/video compression, which are very important if you want to do anything in graphics. Things such as motion estimation and filtering are things that are introduced in 123 and really developed in 225B. EE info theory classes are usually a lot more theoretical/mathy than CS classes.

184 is an intro hodgepodge of random topics that are related to graphics. It's an intro class like 161 where they briefly touch upon many things, but you're only expected to understand them at a surface level. 184 only mentions things such as sampling/aliasing and JPEG, but in 123 you go through the full derivation of why all of this stuff works, and you're expected to implement it yourself from scratch.

I think this would be good for you since you seem to like math enough to do the DE and maybe you would like the material to be presented in a much more rigorous manner.

history.content:
Hey! 

I am currently a freshman, majoring in English and Data Science with Applied Math DE, and am very curious about ML applications in computer graphics/animations. I know CS 184 teaches you some kind of these things, but I am wondering if there are some research groups or other classes that would be helpful to explore such a career path? Thanks.
history.subject: Computer Graphics/Animation
